definition: The ability to enter, use, or get something; to enter or use something.
examples: Students have access to the library after school. (noun)
Use your code to access the portal. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Access = a way to ‘get at’ something.

definition: To connect in your mind; a partner or colleague; joined with something else.
examples: We often associate rain with umbrellas. (verb)
She is a research associate in the lab. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Associate = make a mental ‘association’.

definition: Noisy, energetic, and a little out of control.
examples: The boisterous crowd sang after the win.
Boisterous play is best taken outdoors.

extra.memory_tip: Boisterous = bursting with noise and energy.

definition: Very bright or very clever; excellent.
examples: A brilliant idea solved the problem.
We saw a brilliant flash of lightning.

extra.memory_tip: Brilliant = shines with light or smarts.

definition: A period of ten years.
examples: A decade ago we lived in another city.
The project took nearly a decade.

extra.memory_tip: Deca- = ten, so decade = ten years.

definition: Easily broken or damaged; needing careful handling.
examples: Handle the delicate glass with care.
The butterfly’s wings are delicate.

extra.memory_tip: Delicate = ‘delicate touch’ needed.

definition: Not active or working; to spend time doing nothing or run without working hard.
examples: The machines were idle during the holiday. (adjective)
Cars idled at the red light. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Idle = idling engine—on but not going.

definition: To give or supply what is needed.
examples: The school provides lunch for pupils.
Please provide your name and class.

extra.memory_tip: Provide = ‘pro-vid(e)’—see ahead and supply.

definition: To need something; to make something necessary.
examples: Most plants require sunlight.
The rules require helmets on bikes.

extra.memory_tip: Require = the requirement says ‘must’.

definition: To mock or tease in a mean way; a remark made to anger or upset someone.
examples: Don’t taunt others on the playground. (verb)
He ignored the taunt and walked away. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Taunt = talk that taunts and stings.

definition: Willing to accept feelings, habits, or beliefs that are different from your own; patient.
examples: A tolerant class welcomes new ideas.
Be tolerant of small mistakes.

extra.memory_tip: Tolerant = you ‘tolerate’ differences kindly.

definition: To change something completely, usually for the better.
examples: Sun and water transform seeds into plants.
A good edit can transform your writing.

extra.memory_tip: Transform = new ‘form’ after change.

definition: A wild, natural area where few people live.
examples: They camped in the mountain wilderness.
The park protects a large wilderness area.

extra.memory_tip: Wilderness = ‘wild-ness’ of nature.

definition: Good at using tricks to get what you want; crafty.
examples: The wily fox slipped through the fence.
A wily plan outsmarted the opponent.

extra.memory_tip: Wily = ‘wily old fox’ cleverness.

definition: To produce or give something; to give way; the amount produced.
examples: The farm yields a lot of fruit. (verb)
This year’s wheat yield was high. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Yield = either ‘give’ (produce/allow) or ‘give way’.

definition: To light up; to make something clear or easier to understand.
examples: Lanterns illuminated the path through the woods.
The diagram illuminates how the engine works.

extra.memory_tip: Illuminate = put light on it—literally or in your mind.

definition: To give someone a job; to use something for a purpose; the state of being hired.
examples: The company employs over fifty people. (verb)
She is in the employ of the bank. (noun, formal)

extra.memory_tip: Employ = use or give employment.

definition: The branch of science that studies the origin, structure, and development of the universe.
examples: She is writing a paper on modern cosmology.
Cosmology links physics with astronomy.

extra.memory_tip: Cosmology = cosmos + -logy (study).

definition: To come near in distance or time; a way of dealing with something.
examples: Winter is approaching fast. (verb)
We chose a hands-on approach to learning. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Approach = a path to get close.

definition: To consider something again, especially in order to change an earlier decision or opinion.
examples: After the new data arrived, we re-evaluated our plan.
It’s wise to re-evaluate goals each term.

extra.memory_tip: Re-evaluate = evaluate again with fresh eyes.

definition: Forming a necessary base or core; of central importance; a basic principle.
examples: Reading is a fundamental skill. (adjective)
Know the fundamentals before advancing. (noun plural)

extra.memory_tip: Fundamental = the ‘foundation’ element.

definition: A person who inspires or influences others; a leading light in a field.
examples: Ada Lovelace is a luminary of computing.
The conference featured several scientific luminaries.

extra.memory_tip: Luminary = someone who ‘lights up’ a field.

definition: Very careful and precise, paying great attention to detail.
examples: Her notes are meticulous and clear.
Meticulous planning saved time later.

extra.memory_tip: Meticulous = minute details matter.

definition: Officially chosen for a job or role; past tense of appoint.
examples: She is the appointed chair of the board. (adjective)
They appointed a new director last week. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Appointed = a point was made to choose you.

definition: A building equipped for observing astronomical, meteorological, or other natural phenomena.
examples: We visited the mountain observatory at night.
Data from the observatory confirmed the comet’s path.

extra.memory_tip: Observatory = a place to observe the sky.

definition: Proof that something is true or correct; the act of verifying.
examples: We received confirmation of the booking.
The results gave confirmation of the theory.

extra.memory_tip: Confirmation = the firm ‘yes’ to a claim.

definition: Einstein’s theory describing gravity as the curvature of space-time caused by mass and energy.
examples: General relativity predicts black holes.
The eclipse provided a test of general relativity.

extra.memory_tip: Mass bends space-time—general relativity explains how.

definition: A change of shape, usually by applied force; distortion.
examples: Engineers measured the beam’s deformation.
Heat can cause plastic deformation in metals.

extra.memory_tip: Deformation = departing from the normal form.

definition: A person who is in charge of an organisation, department, or film.
examples: The museum director announced a new exhibit.
The director chose a different ending for the film.

extra.memory_tip: Director = the one who directs others’ work.

definition: A formal discussion on a particular topic; to argue about a subject, especially in a formal manner.
examples: The class held a debate on recycling. (noun)
We debated the pros and cons of the rule. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Debate = deliberate back-and-forth.

definition: Able to be trusted as being accurate or true; commanding and self-confident.
examples: This is the most authoritative guide on the subject.
Her authoritative voice calmed the room.

extra.memory_tip: Authoritative = like an ‘author’ of the facts.
